Objectivley, Jojo's Bizarre Adventure: Stardust Crusader, the third arc of the Jojo saga, is not a perfect anime. Monster of the week format, unusual art, somewhat silly plot. These are not, however, bad points, to one who is willing to accept something like Jojo. However, just like with it's predecessor, Stardust Crusaders is one of the best anime of the year. 
Part 3: Stardust Crusaders focuses on Jotaro Kujo, the grandson of Jospeth Joestar, the main character of Part 2: Battle Tendency. Part 3 introduced the concept of stands - kind of like a spirit that fights for you. It is soon discovered that themain villan from part 1 - Dio Brando, now styled himself DIO, has returned, causing the awakening of Jotaro and Josepth's stands. However, Jotaro's mother has had her own Stand awaken, but it is slowly killing her. Jotaro must go on a journey to defeat DIO, in 50 days, before his mother dies.

Overall, the plot of the first half of Stardust Crusaders isn't the most special thing in the world - there a few interesting twists, but the overall plot isn't incredible. It features a Monster of the Week format, which some would likely not enjoy, but I felt it worked fine with the JoJo formula.


Where the show really shines is it's characters, who are both badasses, idiots, and clowns at the same time. Jotaro and Jospeth are joined by Avdol, an Egyption Fortune Teller, Kakyoin, a student at Jotaro's school, and Polanareff, a Frenchman on his own mission. Each of the characters have at least one or two episodes dedicated to them, and each of them have their own moments to shine. In my own opinion, Jospeth is just as funny as his part 2 version, as he occasionally swears loudly in English - to hilarious effect. He easily is the funniest character. Of the newcomers, I enjoy Polenareff the most, probably.


What is also very special about this show are the crazy fights that take place every episode - they are all terrible people, but they are invariably all cheesy, funny, or over the top in each of their own special ways. They range from old men with a fast bug Stand, to strangely attractive men like Steely Dan (Dan of Steel in official subs). Personally, my stand out was the Wheel of Fortune fight, as it just amps up the hilarity to 11.


The visuals are very...unique. The show looks great, and the fights are animated well, but to a newcomer it might seem all a little insane, as occasionally the whole scene will just be inverted by palette swaps, turning characters green and clothing pink. The soundtrack is also pretty damn good, and this is taking into account the sound effects that are ever-present in the Jojo-Universe.


Overall, Jojo's Bizarre Adventure: Stardust Crusaders is an absolutely blast of an anime - it's not perfect, but with the sheer amount of enjoyment that can be taken from it, there is no need to pick apart it's short comings. Featuring a cast of insane characters, manly fights, and sheer crazy villains and Stands, this anime is sure to be loved by fans of the battle anime genre.

(Note: this review will cover both seasons of Part 3. You have been warned)
By the late 80', ultra manly GAR anime started to die down, kinda like what happened in the early 80' in which the Super Robot genre started to die down in favor of more Real Robot Animes. While the MANIME as it has been nicknamed still popped up from time to time, chances are, it was probably just some anime from the mid 80' that still hadn't finished. In that light, you could say that Stardust Crusaders was a bit of a swan song for that kind of animes. And it shows.
Story:
Thestory is a bit different from the usual Shounen anime, less so for the actual content of it and more so the way it's presented. Usually Shounen anime either have a bunch of unrelated events with a mini arc here or there, or they'll have a bunch of longer arcs with a clear goal. SC is a bit of a mix of the two. There is a clear goal from the The get Go, but the journey there is what's the focus. In that way, it feels almost like a road trip, and the characters kinda treat it that way.

This kind of storytelling has its pros and cons. On the negatives side, the plot often feels disjointed, almost feeling like if it's just meandering around. On the positive side, however, it makes every event feel unique. That's one thing I'll give SC, it's extremely memorable, full of quotable lines and scenes.

That said, it does probably go on for longer than it should. This is moreso prevalent in the anime as every story arc (With one exception) lasts at least two episodes, but even the manga kinda overused it's 5 chapter story arcs.


Characters:


Like I said in my review of the first season, the best thing about Jojo has always been its characters. This is were another of the problem of the whole Road Trip format starts to show, though. Due to that format, most of the characters aren't allowed to develop. The only exceptions are Polnareff and Iggy. However, I don't mind this so long as the characters are good enough by themselves, and they are.

Jotaro is different from our previous protagonists. He's quiet, rude and is a bit of a dick to everyone and everything. That said, I do feel there's enough depth to his character to make him stand out, plus, he's just badass. Polnareff is the closest thing this show has a deteragonist, having easily the most character development out of the entire cast, which, combined with his quirky yet lovable personality, quickly made him my favorite. Joseph has stepped down from his main character role, and weirdly enough, I don't really find him annoying anymore. His jerkassery and general jokester personality has been toned down, and overall just comes off as a very friendly, lovable guy. Kakyoin and Avdol sadly don't get much to do as they both at some point leave the ground for long periods of time, but they're decent enough characters in their own right so I don't mind. Introduced later on is Iggy, he's a bit of a jerk, but he's fun enough in his own right (Even if the joke of him farting in Polnareff's face got old fast) and he actually does have a bit of character arc, so there's at least that.

Then there's the main villain, DIO (Yes, you actually have to write his name like that, it's how it's spelled even in the Japanese version of the Manga). Compared to how he was in PB, he's definitely mellowed down, being more of a cold, calculating villain compared to the large ham he used to be. He's still pretty hammy, just in a different way. I actually really liked this portray, it made him far more threatening and made for a higher contrast for when he goes totally bat shit insane. The rest of the villains are one shot, so aside from a few like Hol Horse, the D'Arby brothers and Vanilla Ice, they don't stand out too much, but they're decent enough threats so there's at least that.


Art:


The art and animation has definitely received an upgrade. It goes for the late SC manga art style, which means everyone has screws for shoulders. It's ridiculous, but I love it. The actual animation has also gotten better, with there being a lot more movement and energy in the fights.

Speaking of the fights, you can't believe how much the introduction of Stands helps. Because of them, every fight feels unique, with my favorites being the Poker Match with the elder D'Arby brother and the fight between Iggy and Polnareff Vs Vanilla Ice, which feels more like the other two trying to stay alive than actually beating him. And of course, how could I not mention the final Jotaro Vs DIO fight. This is one of the longest fights in the whole Manga, yet every bit of it is memorable (I can legitimately quote you many parts of this fight alone)


Sound:


Contrast to the classical instruments used in the last Season, SC goes for straight up rock, with the classical instruments being used for some of the darker songs. I love it. As for the opening themes, "Stand Proud" is a very energetic and is a pure hype machine, but it's got NOTHING on the second opening "END OF THE WORLD" which is basically hype and manliness incarnate.


Voice Acting:


The cast is amazing. Daisuke Ono got into voice acting because of Jojo to begin with, so I'm glad he above anyone else got the role of Jotaro, as he completely earned it. The late great Unsho Ishizuka replaces Tomokazu Sugita as Joseph, and he's amazing, being able to bring so much joy and life into his character. Fuminori Komatsu hasn't had much work aside from Polnareff, which confuses me as he was fantastic in this role. Of course, then there's also Takehito Koyasu as DIO. I just... what can I say about his performance that hasn't been said already? He's perfect, and you can tell he was having fun with the role. The rest are fantastic too, from Ikue Otani, Masaya Onokasa, Daisuke Hirakawa, Kenta Miyake, Reiko Takagi and even Kentaro Ito. But my absolute favorite casting choice has to be Show Hayami as Vanilla Ice, simply because of the fact that this isn't the first time he has played the role. Yeah, same goes for Daisuke Ono, but this is doubly so for Hayami considering that the last time he played Ice was in a PSX/DREAMCAST GAME! That's... that's just insane.


Overall:


Like with the last season, Stardust Crusaders isn't perfect, but it doesn't have to be. It tells a fun, memorable story that is sure to stick with you. I can definitely see why Japan loves this part so much.


Final Score: 7/10

HOLY SHIIIIIT....this is good.
Jojo's Bizarre Adventure: Stardust Crusaders is just amazing, taking what the foundations of the first season of Jojo's Bizarre Adventure and ratchet up the bizarreness and craziness have now having a more refined edge to itself while also adding in past incidents coming into the light all under the initial premise, this first half of Stardust Crusaders anyways as Around the World in 80 Days: Jojo's Edition with Stands as the primary obstacles. What does kickstart this season is Holly Kuujou (Joseph Joestar's daughter) who awakens her Stand and with Dio reawakened, Joseph, his delinquent grandson Jotaro, Mohammed Abdul an acquaintance ofJoseph journeys to Egypt in order to defeat Dio and stop Holly's Stand so that it doesn't kill her.


Being the first half of Stardust Crusaders, this season just throws most of Dio's servants who are now essentially enemy Stands after the group, some become allies, MOST are generic bad guys with Occult Tarot cards in the Major Arcana as their theming of each Stand (this includes the main cast). The thing with Tarot Cards and by extension the Enemy Stands themselves is of how they perfectly embody their Tarot card they symbolize even to the situation Jotaro and the group and though they are Jobbers meant to show Jotaro and the group's Stand powers, some of them however have more interpersonal rivalry allowing for more character development from the new characters of this season. On speaking of which...


The new cast for this season, aside from Joseph Joestar, are all new but VERY quickly LA loved the cast with all their banter, investment to their beliefs (be it fighting etc.) and just their quirky side that made them REALLY REALLY memorable and they're just badass awesome which is typical at this point in Jojo's. Let's start with Jotaro Joestar voiced by Daisuke Ono, a delinquent but having a heart of gold as much as his stoicism makes it hard for him to show it, though he is one of the more overpowered characters especially with his Stand Star Platinum, thankfully Stardust Crusaders gives lots of limelight to the rest of the main globe trekking group. Joseph Joestar is still Joseph even after soo many years, though he tries to be the instant expert at everything and fails but nonetheless he's integral to the journey even if his powers has diminished, his new Stand Powers helps regardless, he's Joseph through and through and still strong as his teenager years just more in the mental side than his physical side this time. Mohammed Abdul voiced by Kenta Miyake being an acquaintance of Joseph but he's pretty much the "play by the book" serious guy but he is generally the character to keep most of the cast in check as it were if Joseph is out of commission. Noriaki Kakyouin voiced by Daisuke Hirakawa, a highschooler and once enslaved by Dio but after he switches sides, he has some shining moments but other than that he is mostly the least developed character in the cast, his default personality becomes indifferent but with some strong sense of loyalty but not much after that, again his shining moments helps but still and finally we have Jean-Pierre Polnareff voiced by Fuminori Komatsu, who like Kakyouin was enslaved by Dio, but once he switches sides, he is usually the buttmonkey of the group BUT having the most development, coming in much later in the season all due his revenge of defeating the person who killed his sister which leads into a huge revenge conga line, Polnareff is the biggest butt monkey of the season to the point that he has an affinity to shit (no seriously) throughout the journey but damn if he became memorable VERY quickly after his heel face turn. If there was LA's favorite character then it would be Joseph Joestar, his Engrish one-liners are just sooo funny and Joseph still being badass even after all these years but LA will also mention Polnareff not only for his development as a character but he's closest to an audience surrogate in a ways by the end of it especially concerning the plot twists.


Where is Dio in all this?, well he's still in the shadows of Egypt and since Dio is essentially throwing his minions to try and kill the group, the true final boss has not shown himself and to be fair LA will say this makes sense as this season is trying to get to Egypt in the first place thus showing him of what he is capable of now would be meaningless, leave the best til last as it were. 


So in terms of the Stands, the Stands at the start, LA saw the Stands are the upgraded manifestation of the Ripple powers and though it isn't explicitly told that it is, early on it makes it out like that, yes the Stands are by the fact a visual manifestation of the user's talent but nonetheless the Stands themselves are an excellent addition to Jojo's, why?, because the Stand Fights themselves is what shines brightest from the previous season of Jojo's before it, it's the adage of "expecting the unexpected" and sure LA and probably the audiences knows that the main characters can't exactly die and they will always find the way of defeating the enemy Stand, but it's not the result of each fight where the satisfaction comes in, it's the circumstances and how Jotaro and the group handles the threat throughout is where it comes from not to mention how each of the fights portray itself, as intense, impactful and while it's expositioning what the enemy Stands or their own Stand powers are like, it's just the visceral craziness that just stands out (pun intended but you get the point) and seriously some fights are just batshit insane and Stardust Crusaders wears this on it's sleave 24/7 and KNOWS how to handle it's own craziness. 


LA will say the obvious but every time Star Platinum does his ORA! is like the most beautiful sound all because that impact just makes it soo worth it. 


As for the Enemy Stands, LA will say that Death was memorable if only because of showing what Kakyouin is made of outside his normal demeanor as well as Hanged Man due to his connection with Polnareff but more so with Justice. The Lovers just showed what would happen if you crossed Jotaro over and over again and the Empress showed off that Joseph still got it. Hol Horse, The Emperor was probably the longest lasting Enemy Stand but he was killed off too soon oddly enough. The only other Enemy Stand that LA actually found not like the rest of the batshit craziness of Stardust would had been...The Sun. Overall the enemy Stands though they have a mixed reaction overall to LA, they were an integral addition to the journey to Egypt, absolutely. 


In terms of animation and sound, well like the first season, David Production has the same flair as it's first season right down to the erratic yet purposeful switching of color palettes to show the mood and atmosphere but considering that Stardust Crusaders is showing the world (well mainly East to Middle Asia to United Arab Emirates), the backgrounding has LOTS of great exotic backgrounding work because of this. The character designs are typically distinct as hell and even the crazy facial reactions of the characters (mostly from Joseph but some of the enemy Stands also stands out in this regard) and thus memorable (mainly main cast of course) but like the first season David Production brings back the iconic ゴゴゴゴ for the visual sound effects and doesn't hold back to the gorey or more bloody fights uncensored and it is fucking glorious AND add in the great impactful sound effects and timing of the OST's to the fights making every Stand Fight to not make you turn away from the screen, it just heightens the Stand fights even more and with David Production's flair it already gave Jojo's only makes the Stand fights even more awesome. What else can LA say but David Production done it again!


Voice work is damn good, with new cast from Unshou Ishizuka as Joseph Joestar, Daisuke Ono as Jotaro, Fuminori Komatsu as Polnareff, Kenta Miyake as Abdul and hell Rie Kugimiya even played a minor role!. But nonetheless though the main cast has a strong voice cast and they "know" their roles, LA will say the voice cast in general is just amazing, considering the craziness of Stardust Crusaders, even the enemy Stand user's voice actors ALSO did a great job. Ohh and considering this is Jojo's we're talking about...yeah...it's FULL ham from the majority of the cast but the good ham.


LA threw lots of praise at Stardust Crusaders, but was there any flaws in this first season, if at all?, well not so much actually, as even though the enemy Stands brings up padding bringing up obstacles for Jotaro and the group, it's for the most part showing off how awesome Jotaro or the character that is fighting the Stand look awesome, the padding allowing the main cast to mingle more and grow their camaraderie together as well as individually when the enemy Stand targets them and heck NOT having enemy Stands that blocks the group from Egypt would just make the journey soo bloody easy that this season wouldn't exist in the first place and they would have been in Egypt by the second episode and that would be no fun at all. The only other thing would be toilet humor but to be honest it's fine, adding a bit of comedy to the proceedings that counterbalances the batshit insanity the journey to Egypt entails. So LA really can't find many strong flaws in Stardust Crusaders as it becomes nitpicking than finding flaws in it, not to mention how LA defends those small flaws...Stardust Crusaders' first season is just that good and we're only looking at the "journey" portion to getting to Dio!...heck we haven't even touched the "finding and defeating" part yet!.


Stardust Crusaders' first season though has a simple premise of trying to get to Egypt but enemy Stands stops Joseph and Jotaro at every turn but at the very least, this first season gets us used to the new cast, develop them and get them acclimated to Jotaro and Joseph's cause as well as budding camaraderie with the main cast through their journey making them vastly memorable through the 24 episodes, the Stands and by extension, the fights, the highlights of the first season makes what is a episodic format of facing off against each Stand user "looks like padding" but still make the padding enjoyable and batshit crazy awesome in the process and THAT is a hard feat to do and Stardust Crusaders' first season execution in that was done well. So the journey to Egypt was crazy fun, how about the journey to face off against Dio...well that is something LA just can't wait to see and this first season being buildup wasn't a waste of time, no it was an enjoyable crazily fun experience all the way through, LA can't wait to see Battle for Egypt!!!


ORA!!!

After all the mediocre seasonal animes we have been getting a light shines through all the filth and that light is Jojo's bizarre adventure: Stardust Crusaders. This is easily the best anime of the season, it blows the rest out of the water. no seasonal anime can compare to this masterpiece. it would be an insult to Araki Hirohiko who wrote this manly series. Now I lie in wait for January to witness the greatness that is coming in the Egypt saga.

This is not a great anime. But it's not a bad anime, and if you're a fan of the Jojo series, you should watch it so you can continue the series. 
Now I love the Jojo series and I loved Stardust Crusaders Season 2. But in season 1 of Stardust Crusaders, we were introduced to a protagonist who, for the vast majority of the season, is a complete as$hat (pun intended), and we lose Ripple in favor of Stands, which are basically just Personas (as in from the Shin Megami Tensei series). And it made no sense. I mean, Jojo and Polnaref are literally thetwo buffest guys on the show, to the point that their muscles are literally popping out of their clothes, yet their Stands are (1) a punching Stand, and (2) a fencing Stand. You're telling me that Jotaro couldn't have just learned to punch for himself, and Polnaref couldn't put those abs to good use? But the worst thing about Stardust Crusaders Season 1 was it felt so repetitive. The gang was basically just trudging through Storm Trooper after Storm Trooper for so many episodes, and it didn't help that the main characters were so shallow. Jotaro's entire persona can be summed up with "I'm a badas$," and that’s it. This is right after we were treated to the brilliance of a young and charmingly dorky Joseph Joestar, and his Indiana Jones-like action-adventure. The other characters also did not really develop and become interesting until the second season, especially Polnaref. In Season 1, Polnaref was all about revenge, which is such a cheap plot mechanic. I'm so glad the anime moved away from that plot point in Season 2, where Polnaref, and everybody else, really shined. Season 1 mostly felt like filler episodes compared to Season 2, where the characters become much more interesting, the battles become much more creative, and the story kicks it up a notch. So hang in there!

Jojo's bizarre adventure keeps on getting more bizarre and adventurous, but does it get more Jojo? This is part 3: stardust crusaders, which is split in half between 2 seasons, both of which are 24 episodes long, and both of which I'll be reviewing today.
STORY 3/10
The story is the bringer of some of the best and worst aspects of this show. This takes place decades after part 2, and depicts an old joeseph joestar, now married with grandchildren. His wife has a curse put on her by the evil, muscular and (not gonna lie) sexy DIO BRANDO. Jojo, his grandson, jotaro and a diverse groupof other people have to travel the world to meet dio and lift this curse, but with a time limit. This sounds excited, right? It is, about a quarter of the time. To put it bluntly, this show doesn't have to be 48 episodes. All but about 10 of these episodes are them encountering a villain-of-the-week, and a majority of them are completely useless. The villains are often throw always, the characters hardly learn anything, and sometimes the plots are downright cringey. With that said, there is a large handful of great episodes that had me laughing my ass off, kept me captivated, or moved the plot (which doesn't happen too much).


CHARACTERS 6/10

Oh boy there's a lot of them. The main cast of characters can be boiled down to Jojo and his squad. Joseph, jotaro, Avdol, Polnareff, and Kakyoin. Every one of those characters (except for Jotaro) has a large number of episodes centering around them and their mini, solo adventures. That's how the show works, every episode or 2 follows a different character facing off against a villain, using special strategies and personality traits to their benefit, which is a good thing. I love how all of these characters (except for Jotaro) have almost equal attention put on them, as well as distinct personality traits. Now as for Jotaro, I fell like he has the least amount of attention put in him, despite what the openings would show you. He's only important at the beginning and at the end, not to mention he has one of the weakest and hardest to write for personality traits: the badass who doesnt like talking to people. Seriously, I can only describe Jotaro using 1 word: quiet. 


The other side of the character spectrum is the villains. There's a whole lot of them, almost 1 for every other episode. I said before that most of the villains are lazy throw always whose only purpose is to work for Dio and kill the main characters. That's true to 98% of them. All of the villains except for Hol Horse, Boingo, Enya and Dio himself fall under the under-developed villain of the week category. Not to mention that the villains are sometimes so annoying, I have a hard time watching the next episode. On top of things, the main villain of the story is Dio, even though he only does things in about 5 episodes. I constantly feel like the show wants me to fear Dio, but I can't because all he ever does is stand in shadows and hiring assassins every week. Whenever he is shown doing things it's awesome, but I prefer my villains to directly face and intimidate the main characters instead of being someone working behind the scenes, detached from the central plot. Don't get me wrong the Dio fights are amazing, tho.


ART 9/10

Once again, Jojo proves to have a super unconventional and distinct art style that I love so much. Part 2 was a lot more psychedelic and colorful, but part 3 has character designs as it's strong point. Looking past the fact that every character is unrealistically muscular, they all have a lot of realism. I can see most of these characters fitting into real life. They'd have really weird hair, but they still look more human than some other anime characters (I'm looking at you, Yu-gi-oh).


OVERALL 7/10

Jojo's bizarre adventure: stardust crusaders is quite the mixed bag when watched critically, but once you're able to look past the flaws, appreciate it for what it is, then you'll realize the overall greatness of these seasons. Yes, there are some un-watchable parts, and yes the show gets boring and drags on for too long, but the great episodes are worth it alone, as well as the references that spawn from this. You should totally watch this series, but just keep these things in your mind.

In general, I think that this part of the manga is one of the most creative by its author, the mood is more funny, the protagonists are very charismatic(well, almost all) and have good appearances in screen, battles are very creative, etc. Even so, the plot is very slow and follow the rhythm is something difficult, since it is very repetitive and predictable, the villains secondary are underused(the great majority) and both the protagonist as the antagonist principal are poorly developed; but this story has interesting things and expands several of the features most notable of JoJo's.
En general, pienso que esta parte del manga esuna de las mas creativas por parte de su autor, el humor es mas gracioso, los protagonistas son muy carismáticos(bueno, casi todos) y tienen buenas apariciones en pantalla, las batallas son muy creativas, etc. Aun así, la trama es muy lenta y seguirle el ritmo es algo difícil, dado a que es muy repetitiva y predecible, los villanos secundarios están poco aprovechados(la gran mayoría) y tanto el protagonista como el antagonista principal están mal desarrollados; pero esta historia tiene cosas interesantes y expande varias de las características mas destacables de JoJo's.

The characters are funny and unique. There's humor as well as a lot of action and gore. It's a crazy and bonkers anime with fast pacing. Nothing more i could ask for a action anime. The story plot although quite basic does interest you and is sensible which is a good thing. The fight scenes are quite intellectual in a sense that it's not just winning with brute strength or power, the characters involved use their brain to outwit and outsmart there opponents time to time which i think enhances the action within this anime. I'd recommend this anime. Its good stuff

Ah Jojo. The mastermind of anime strikes again, this time in its defining season. What happens in this part will impact the rest of the entire series. Part 3 is probably the most popular part of the anime, at least- let's see how it holds up. There will be light spoilers in this. And is kinda a "should you watch this?" review, so just stick with me.
/STORY- 7 OUTTA 10 MEMES\
As you may have seen, in the previous review, after I finished Battle Tendacy, (Part 2) I was hooked. I wanted more, and I got it. This is JJBApt3, but part 3 itself is intwo parts. Yes, there is another season of SC, but that review is for another day.


So anyway, what's the story? Well, JJBA takes another timeskip (as it does 99% of the time) to another Jojo. But let's get the main part of this thing out of the ways first. STANDS. I have to admit, not to exaggerate, but Stands are one of the best things ever created in media, and their idea and concept is amazing. All of them are named/related to songs/albums/bands/covers, so it provides a unique way to make a self-insert if you want to make your own storyline. And Stands are what defined Jojo, still being used in the current part (8).


Remember DIO from part 1? Well, I don't think this is much of a spoiler, because, you know, he's been in every piece of promotional art for this show, but he has been resurrected. He works his magic, and puts Jotaro (the new jojo) 's mother into a coma. So now he, Joseph (who is older now) and a small gang of stand users into a journey from Japan, to Egypt. On foot. And other vehicles occasionally. If they don't crash.


So in every episode, a new member of DIO's gang will come at the Stardust Crusaders. Therefore, this is a "villain of the week story". And yes, I did make a recommendation to another show on this site because of it. While watching this I couldn't help but see similarities to Ore, Twintail ni Narimasu. If you liked this, or want to watch this, I helighly recommend you watch Stardust Crusaders. And if you have watched Stardust Crusaders and haven't seen that show, watch it. Lots of similarities. Even if you don't follow Jojo, but liked one of these two, do it.


So did I like the story? Yeah I did. I think it wasn't the best, as I felt Parts 1 and especially 2 (my second favorite) were much quicker paced.  I think I definitely would have enjoyed this more if I had watched it while it was airing, but I didn't discover JJBA until pt4 (which by the way is my favorite part). 


/ART- 9 STANDOS OUTTA 10\n

The art for the humans is done in the typical Jojo style- same as part 1. DIO (who looked amazing in this by the way) and Joseph's looks have changed, obviously. I think the characters were brighter too, in this portion of the show. Not much to say here that I didn't say I my initial review.


Now, the art for the Stands. The Stands had the best art out of everything. Like I said, they are very unique and define JJBA. Every design is new and different, and Stands can essentially be anything. Of course, this part had the most basic ones, considering this is the first time the series uses Stands. My favorite?


『SILVER CHARIOT』.


/SOUND- 8 OUTTA 10 EGYPTIANS\n

I'll be the roundab- Wait, wrong part. The OP for Jojo had changed once again- this time to the aptly named, Stand Proud. I think both of the original OPs (I'm referring to Sono chi no Sadame and Bloody Stream) were better, and this was probably my second least favorite theme of the show in general. But it was still great, just wasn't my favorite.


And the ED Walk Like An Egyptian was even better.


/CHARACTER- 8 OUTTA 10 STAND USERS\n

Alright, I want to start this off by saying, Stands have no personality. They are just fighters. So the characters are the humans of the show:


JOTARO KUJO: The new Jojo, and main character. He has another different personality than the other Jojos. Definately not my favorite Jojo, but not the worst. None of them are 'bad' per say, I just thought this was my least favorite out of the anime so far. I think he gets better in Part 4 (plus I like his character design better there too)


JOSEPH JOESTAR: 👌 as usual. I explained him in my other review. He hasn't changed much, just he's older now. And I have to admit, despite being "weak" I like Hermit Purple's power.


KAKYOIN: I liked him a lot. Not my favorite from this part, probably my third favorite for original characters. Hierophant Green was a sort of forgettable Stand though.


AVDOL: My second favorite character. He was different, and I liked his design. I felt he stood out from the rest the best. I wasn't crazy about his Stand though either.


POLERNAFF: Hands down, best, dankest character. Everything about his personality was great, and he was the most overall likeable one. Plus, most badass stand, Silver Chariot.


Note: DIO isn't here because he doesn't show up until the second season. There really aren't any main villains for this part.


/ENJOYMENT: 6 CRASHING AIRPLANES OUTTA 10\n

While I did really enjoy Stardust Crusaders, I couldn't help but feel that I had more enjoyment in the first season of this show. I thought some parts were well, sort of boring. Like, Death Note (imo read my review) level boring. Granted, it was only about 5 episodes, and I can't even really put my finger on which episodes they were in particular, but I just wanted to get to the next stand. The best moments of the series were the reveal of new stands, but the middle bit before the Stand got defeated, was just boring for the most part. The latter half, SC: Season 2, I feel is much better in this regard (and overall, but that's for another day). So, this being said, I think this series would have been best to watch airing. I think watching SC episode after SC episode, actually detracts from the viewing experience. So if you're reading this review wonder what you should do, I feel it's best to watch only 1-3 episodes at a time, then taking a break ad doing something else on your computer, then opening the tab again, instead of watching 7 in a row like me.


/OVERALL- 7 OUTTA 10 STAR PLATINUMS\n

Anyways, that was the experience for Stardust Crusaders. Overall, do I think you should watch Stardust Crusaders? Yes, yes I do, especially if you loved JJBA Pt1 & 2. I even think SC is fine to watch even if you have no intention of following Jojo (Like not watching what comes before and after) since the formula is much different from parts 1, 2, and 4. 


I hope you enjoyed my review!

I already started JoJo 2 months ago, i see every chapter carefully and i am prepared for write this.
Story: 7/10
Stardust Crusaders starts in a pefect way: In just 24 minutes, the Anime put in the screen the objective (Defeat DIO), and in 2 chapters more they put another important character and a situation than inmediatly starts the adventure of the Joestar Family. So much people says than this is a boring story because there's no plotwist, and yeah, all the Anime is dedicated on development and not in execution. Thisis fine for ONE reason:\n\n
Characters: 8/10\n
Phantom Blood and Battle Tendency characters sucks compared with those characters. Probably Jotaro is not as good as Joseph, but is SO much better than Jonathan because HIS DEVELOPMENT. Jotaro is probably the first JoJo with develop (this is more clear in Diamond Is Unbreakable) and in the meantime, the other characters are good tho (especially Polnareff, than is my favorite escort of the part and a better character than Jotaro).\n\n
Nothing too much to say. The art and the sountracks are fine (specially the opening) and i actually ejoy the return of DIO and all the mistery envolved in him. In this moment, Stardust Crusaders 1 and 2 are my favorite parts of JoJo like Anime, let's see how the Manga is.

The whole season in one quote by Joseph Joestar in the last episode:
“Indeed. In a jet, this trip would've taken twenty hours. But it took us thirty days”
If you can afford a freaking submarine you could as well buy or rent a fucking jet. At this point I don't even want to know if it was just an oversight or was it intentional.
Add to this repetitive episodes, very weak plot twists (speak about Avdol), uselessness of hamon, overall less memorable characters (despite greater number of them) and unimpressive concept of Stands compared to fights in season one.
I've greatly enjoyed Phantom Blood and Battle Tendency arcs,but Stardust Crusaders was a great disappointment and felt like a series of fillers to me. \n\n

This season of JoJo did not feel as good as the previous season, i.e., Battle Tendencies. While Battle tendencies spiced itself up with a multitude of jokes and bizarre comments and what not, this season lacked in that. 
The only major story development in this season was of them going all the way from japan to Egypt. The first few episodes start off strong and the initial enjoyment is very high, but overtime, one tends to get bored of the constant repetition of things and ideas. 
We got to discover only a few things about the lead characters; we have almost no history and knowledgeabout the character's pasts and what makes them that way. The reason for coming in of the Stands was not defined well enough. 


The sounds were amazing, though they lacked when compared to Battle Tendencies. But one major improvement in this series was the animation and the art. The thought put into it was amazing! The artists managed to keep the overly muscular and animated forms and that vintage feel while ensuring that they actually enhanced their animations and art style! That was a commendable action on their part. 


Also, the suspense is real! The creators have to slyly managed to hide Jotaro's power from the audience. The only reference to his power in this season is raw strength, which is a great build up for any possible boosts in the next season. Also Dio's face is never shown so that makes the hype much more!


All in all, I feel that this season had way too many unnecessary parts that did not contribute anything to the story but rather pulled it down. Nevertheless, it sets the stage for season 2 of Stardust Crusaders in a rather decent manner.

Well, this review proceeds as follows: I will speak only of these episodes, not the entire saga. Here I will review only the points of this first part of Stardust in anime, that is, it will not enter criticism to the next part, as villains and etc. My review on Part 2 will get all the rave reviews about the entire bow that was adapted from the manga.
Story: Well, here we have something complicated, one point I would like to put about it, is this: the story is not very rich, it is not a bad story, but, it manages to pass the feeling ofadventure very well. In this part of the anime, we have several scenes where they focus on the geographical locations, this is very good, because for an adventure anime this is necessary. The change of scenery, according to the famous places they go by, is something excellent and well done.\n
Speaking of the proposed story, she tackles events from part 1, and intends to end the confrontation Joestars vs. Dio. To summarize: Stardust's story in this first part, does not have many deep moments, does not have much development, but ends up hitting the adventure and environmentalism, that is, it is a very medium and fun story.\n
Arte e som: A arte em anime, é muito bem feita, e isso foi um acerto muito grande da DP, pois o manga é antigo, e seus traços seriam ruins para um anime atual. O anime ainda mantém as características do autor, mas com um tom mais moderno e suavizado. A animação não é ruim\n
Som: David Productions é uma das melhores produtoras quando se trata de efeitos sonoros. Durante toda a parte, temos uma qualidade imensa nas edições de áudio. As trilhas sonoras não decepcionam, mas não são sensacionais ou grandiosas. \n
Here's the point where I really want to talk.\n
The characters are not exactly amazing on technical issues, and half of them follow a template created in that saga, the model of facing a "villain", he being defeated, and then begin to help the protagonists.\n
Basically the motivations are not deep, they are not very complex, but they are fun, they work well inside the anime, and they are not incoherent.\n
What I will say now, I will repeat in my next review, the characters of SC, although they are not the best, are the most striking among ALL parts of Jojo's. Maybe this is not a rule, maybe someone has been more captivated by other characters from other parties, but the majority of them are the most charismatic and captivating, talking about secondary characters who are essentially protagonists.\n
Finally, I had a great time with this first part. It really was a unique and different experience, especially by the author inserting the stands in the manga universe.\n
What you need to expect from SC in this first part is basically a completely different experience from the previous ones (Phatom Blood and Battle Tendency), enemies with miraculating powers, almost always crazy solutions, to defeat the enemies, and a dose of humor that pleases often.\n
A very average anime, I can not speak much more, because I must remember that this part is one, but in anime, it was divided by technical issues of the producer.\n

Absolutely Iconic. When people think of JoJo's this is what everyone means. This is where the show starts to really shine and show its true colors and influences prominently. Also stand's and Old Man Joseph, need i say more? Ok i will. The thing holding stardust crusaders back from a 10 out of me was it felt too much like a villain of the week show. I liked our villains a lot. much like every character in JoJo's every character is lively and handled in way that doesn't have our boys finishing every fight the same (having certain members present during fights keeps things fresh)and having them outsmarting the villains they encounter is a great game of how far thinking the other is.

After reading Parts 1 and 2 of Jojo's Bizarre Adventure last year, I was really itching to go onto the next part, Stardust Crusaders. I was leaning towards reading them having read the first two, as I heard the original anime of Part 3 was rather off from the original storyline of the manga. Note that I am basing my rating on this for the genre as a whole, not the entirety of anime.
Luckily, as if by fate, I found out that a new anime was being released of JoJo. I also found out about the first 2 Parts, but not until I started watchingit.


The story starts off with protagonist, Jotaro Kujo, residing in a jail cell, having beaten up a bunch of hooligans using a so-called "Evil Spirit". His grandfather, Joseph from Part 2, turns up from America with Egyptian acquaintance Muhammed Avdol.  It soon turns out that they he has an spiritual manifestation known as a 'Stand'. 

At this point, I was excited having found out about the series through it's titular bizarreness, the fabulousity and the Stands. It kind of replaces the 'Hamon' power of the last instalments, but makes up for it with awesomely crazy and creative abilities that the Stands have in their arsenal. My only little niggle with this is that I really would have liked to see Hamon brought back into usage along with Stands for a few more creative fighting styles, but seeing as how the stories have played out, I don't really care all that much as it makes sense. 9/10 for Story.


About the graphical apparel this show wears...it is brilliant, it's like i'm using a Stand ability myself that allows me to animate manga (and colour it). That may sound really stupid, but it's not far off from some of the techniques utilized by a lot of them. I haven't even watched it in HD and it still looks crisp and detailed on most, if not all of the important scenes and even ones that don't even matter that much. 10/10 for Art.


The VAs pulled an impressive job in this, especially for Jotaro's no-care attitude and especially Joseph's "OH MY GAARRD!". Despite it being engrish, due to the theme of the anime, it really made it that much funnier hearing it. Don't even get me started on the Openings. Some might find them lacking, for a lack of a better term, compared to other anime. They WILL get in your head eventually, even if you fight it. 

Also, expect to hear an "OraOraOra" every once and a while, it really makes fight scenes satisfying.  Also "Rerorerorero" will get you. 10/10 for Sound.


The main cast really is a big bunch of misfits, with Jotaro as the guy who seriously doesn't want to take any bull from you, Joseph as the wacky grandpa and Avdol as a rather stern and (ironically) cold individual that will still make you laugh. I would say more about the other protagonists, but that may be spoilers to some people.

Aside from the main protagonists and the villains, most people don't really have a say in anything and normally end up dying or being pushed aside as something minor. To be honest, I rather like it as it means the story refrains from dragging on or trying to pull out something interesting and then pushing it aside. It helps you to feel more attached to the main lot, anyway. 

9/10 for Character.


I seriously couldn't stop watching it. I learned that going to the toilet in certain parts of the world is a no-go, dogs like coffee-falvoured chewing gum and, hey, even Avdol taught me how to drink Chai properly (SPOILER ALERT!). 

The story really keeps you on your toes as to what kind of stand will appear next. Despite the lack of Hamon, it really shows that it was probably the right choice to have more of the Stands instead. 10/10 for Enjoyment.


Overall, I really enjoyed it. It has the laughs, the cool and even the tears. 

All the while remaining perfectly fabulous.


10/10

I was a little familiar with Stardust Crusaders before I ever even watched JoJo's Bizarre Adventure, and after binge-watching Battle Tendency, I fell in love with how amazing it was and immediately started binge-watching this.
Even though so many things about the two seasons are the same, I felt disappointed with this one. I hated that hamon seemed to have disappeared all together, only being mentioned a few times. It took a long time for the idea of Stands to grow on me, and even now, I only tolerate them. While I think the villain's stands were interesting, I grew bored very quickly with the maincasts Stands. None of them really left an impression, despite their different qualities.


Another thing that bothered me was the fact that, despite the show being called JoJo's Bizarre Adventure, Joturo was more like a background character. I'm glad that Joseph was still a part of the show, but shouldn't the other Joestar also be included in more ways than simply saying "good grief" over and over?


Nonetheless, there were good things about this season. I found all of the main characters likable, the art and music was great as always, and I loved the odd humor.  There were many moments that really put the "bizarre" in JoJo's Bizarre Adventure. This season didn't wrap up very well, but I hope season three is better than this one.

Jojo's Bizarre Adventure, probably one of the anime I love/hate, hate to love and love to hate the most. Araki's writing has never quite been the most consistent, but god damn does he deliver. JBA has three parts, with Stardust Crusaders being responsible for the introduction of the concept of Stands, as well as the boom in popularity for the series. Divided into two seasons, this is the first half of it.
Story: 4
Araki's writing is not quite the best, with various cliches and inconsistencies, Stardust Crusaders is structured like a "fight corridor", as in it is very episodic, where they meet an opponent during thefirst half of a given episode, defeat it in the other, rinse and repeat until a major villain appears. But it still delivers on interesting encounters, and manages to make good use of the concept of stands, which are the anime's concept of "special powers".


Art: 7


Jojo's art is probably the most beautiful style you'll see. Practically ignoring the style that is present basically everywhere. Able to be both bright and colorful, as well as dark and grim, its extremely versatile. The characters look great, the stands are unique and creative.


But Jojo still suffers from araki's "brain farts", as in characters randomly follow absurd proportions, the infamous "17 year old who naturally looks like a top tier bodybuilder", and other visual inconsistencies.


Sound: 9


The OST is amazing, with it's openings being praised by the fanbase, and the outro (for the first season) is the famous Roundabout, by none other than Yes. The SFX is well made, with unique sounds for fights. And the Va...well the VA is good, but it has its moments (aka Joseph's engrish being a turn off for some people).


Character: 5


The characters are interesting, but somewhat bland a lot of times, their motivations range from anywhere from "I want to save my mother from my bloodline's curse" to "Yeah, you're a cool guy, I'm with you". In Stardust Crusaders, the majority of characters feel more like a means to an end, that end being intense fighting.


Enjoyment: 8


Not a lot to say here, I really liked it, its unique, it serves well the "rule of cool" without being enslaved by it, of course, some problems become glaring at times, which is why I give it an 8, not a 9.


Overall: 8


If you want amazing action sequences, unique sound design, art style, and a badass power system, then I greatly recommend watching Stardust Crusaders

Dark, gritty, horrific and most especially BIZARRE, JoJo's Bizarre Adventure tends to adapt the Manga/Anime sides of things quite nicely, for the genre is known to be quite unusual in and of itself but sidetracking...
JoJo's Bizarre Adventure is a unique series in and of itself for that it not only features a sole main protagonist, rather, it features a whole family of them! from different eras and with especially different personalities and appearances, these JoJos are not the kind of people you want to mess with when picking a side in a fight.
JoJo's story line develops throughout eras in mankind's history starting from the late1880s and builds over the courses of 8 individual respective Story Arcs with equally 8 individual respective "JoJos" that all belong and/or are connected in some way to the same family of truly heroic human beings known, as the Joestar Family.


If there was ever a family that has known too much tragedy in its life, its the Joestars, nevertheless, tragedy has never broken their strong wills and free spirits, time and time again, they have defied the evil forces that have tried to suppress them and even then, the Joestars have only come out stronger because of such actions...


JoJo's Bizarre Adventure is the ever evolving story of good versus evil, light versus darkness, yang and yin, white and black, etc...the Joestars representing all that is good and pure in the world against the evil and dark forces that would try to consume the world in pure malice...


However, as it clearly states in the title of the series, the fight against evil becomes that of a bizarre adventure, taking unique twists and turns all on the path to reach the end.


JoJo truly stands out by the time it reaches the 3rd Story Arc of the franchise, Stardust Crusaders which in a way can be seen, as a kind of reboot for the series, as a whole, also, it gives new viewers to JoJo who are starting out watching the series a chance to start fresh less they wish to watch the entire story, as a whole and start from the very 1st Story Arc.


I never really noticed it until later on but poses and other actions featured in JoJo became memes on the internet and/or are featured in Japanese pop culture, showing that JoJo has become an influential series on expanding the Manga/Anime culture.


JoJo is a good story to watch from its beginning but i say that it reaches a new height for popularity by the time Stardust Crusaders begins, for Stardust introduces the Story, Art, Sound, Character, Enjoyment and Overall of JoJo to a whole new level, giving viewers things they might very well have not expected.


However-A word of caution to viewers, JoJo's Bizarre Adventure is not for the faint of heart and i can most definitely say now that it should only be watched by viewers 15 and up, if anyone below that age...just be prepared to have nightmares cause JoJo will have that effect on you, please heed my warning and don't say i didn't warn you.


JoJo also debates great controversy for those who look closely and see what can be said is wrong about it, other then my warning and the controversial bits of JoJo, it is a great series to watch for any Manga/Anime fan, just, as so long, as you are prepared, you are in one heck of a surprise of the unexpected.


For JoJo is exactly that-the unexpected.


I hope my Review was helpful to everyone.

Oh look it's the third JoJo, the shit one.
Okay, okay I'm just a teeny weeny completely flustered by the amount of bad parts this JoJo series contains.
I oughta start with story this time around, despite story in JoJo being completely overlooked in favor of characters, cause it contains this run's supernatural punch power thingy. This being Stands. Stands are manifestations of one's life force and have special abilities or in some cases they just punch things. In short think Shaman King or Digimon. The story isn't too complex, albeit a bit too much like part one. A colorful group of humans with supernaturalabilities go on a journey to beat up a vampire named DIO facing his lackeys during their way to DIO's doom fortress. Yep it's pretty much Phantom Bloody with more spirit-life force-things and less Hamon, oh and Joseph's daughter named Holy who's dying because of Dio fever(aren't we all?).

There are two parts of this anime. Pre-Egypt one and Egypt one. Both come with a huge number of enemies with varying Stand powers. It does soon become like Power Rangers with an enemy-of-the-week style of episodes. Now it wouldn't be a problem if we'd at least get a little bit of background on characters, which is a rarity in pre-Egypt , or some time to actually dislike them but it's rather rare that we get that. I'd say first 11 episodes were pretty nice despite some villains suffering from enemy-of-the-week blandness. However after that most of the pre-Egypt one is spent with boring fights. There are two entertaining ones in the form of Death 13 and Judgment. After that we have Egypt. The enemies there have some more characteristics to their characters and overall create more interesting situations. I'll give story a 6 cause it had good bits but it's overall way too flawed. I did get a bit into characters by talking about enemies so let's go down that path and discuss them some more ,cause therein lies the problem methinks. 


Let's start with the main cast. Jotaro is protagonist of this adventure. He's also an obnoxious git that I loathe more than the guy in the pizza shop who always gives me the smallest slice. He's obviously supposed to be misanthropic arse who doesn't give two squirts bout anything especially being courteous. Now granted Joseph was an asshole on occasions but he didn't feel like a sandpaper ball rubbing your prostate trough your bum. Jotaro also has that ,,too cool for you fool,, feeling to him which doesn't help with getting my sympathy. Overall I didn't found anything endearing about him, like Joseph's wisecracking attitude or Jonathan's extreme macho sweat-dripping manliness. But wait he's got a supporting cast of colorful characters too. First in line being Joseph who probably obtained his attire from a certain archeologist. He's less wisecracky this time around but his engrish catchphrases add some, if a bit bothersome, character to him. There's Tyr-... I mean Avdol who's more of a straight character, and that's pretty much it. There's Polnareff who's much more interesting than our protagonist. Polnareff is the one getting into reaaallly weird *cough* bizarre *cough* situations. He also reacts in a more human manner rather than Jotaro's annoying reaction deprived face. There's Kakyoin who has some trippy trips on his own. He and Polnareff are the stars of pre-Egypt part only rivaled with Joseph and Avdol's brotastic adventures. Egypt however kills even those fun parts, excluding an adventure or two Polnareff had. The dialogue goes down to. Mistar Joustaaaarr, OH MAII GOOUD, We have to find Dio, We have to help Holy, Where's Dio, What's that Stand's power.

Pretty much the extent of it. It's funny, or annoying, that heroes and villains characters are inversely proportional. Villain's, well most of them, get more depth and heroes lose 90% of theirs.

Here's a 6 for characters cause I enjoyed some of the interactions early on.


Art follows the same pattern as everything else in here. It fluctuates from good to mediocre trough both parts more so in Egypt part than pre-Egypt. And even more annoying is that characters are even more indistinguishable than before, everybody looking exactly the same with the exception of their hair. I won't stick to animation too much but I do think that it deserves an 8. Even at it's lowest point it's better than most animation, and first OP looks like chocolate pudding stripper with cream bikini(take that comparison however you want).


Sound. Sound is still JoJo-y and wonderful. Second opening is a poop but first one is the usual blood boiling macho fest. So here's a 9, I'm prepared to forgives some fall outs.


I enjoyed this part but not as much as others. It was a mixed bag of fun, thrilling fights and meh ones. Some were so meh that I lost interest in writing this paragraph preemptively. Here's a 7 cause 8 was a bit too much considering how often they screwed the pooch.


Overall is a 7 as this is the worst installment. Now I'd say the biggest problem are characters. Hey, fellow anime watcher. If you're wondering, how this anime gets so many positive feedback, and looking for negative, than here is one. 
The D. D for Dissapointment. 
Assuming anyone reading this review watched "Phantom Blood" and "Battle Tendency" already, I'm going to compare these two to "Stardust Crusaders". 
So, after this incredible and bizzare adventure show kinda left you hanging with the ending. And you're coming for more... But I want to stop you there. 
Story. 
It changes pace immensely, without any warning. It tries to fool you that many, yes, a lot of filler episodes that there is actually mean something. Amazing journeythat you saw in previous show now turned into Dora the Explorer kinda adventure. Sounds fun? Then get used to rambling and many unnessesary situations.\n
Characters. \n
"Stands were a mistake" (c) robozaec, 2017\n
There is a lot, a f*ckton of characters, whose existense is justified only for making another mindless filler episode. With that big quantity of characters you'd expect a quality loss. And you're right. There are many irritating ones, that make you feel bad even looking at them a couple seconds. And there are whole episodes dedicated to them. Sometimes even two (aka part one and part two). \n
Don't get me wrong, some characters aren't like that, but that's a minority. \n
Oh, silly me, I forgot to mention the star of the show. And you know why I always forget about him? Because JoJo in "Stardust Crusaders" doesn't have character. When in PB and BT it always felt like JoJo did what his heart led him to do, or his muscles maybe, while Jotaro acts like a doll. His "manliness" and "dark nature" seems forced a lot. It seems like director keeps its audience for idiots, and thinks that it's enough to just say, that "JoJo always used to be a hooligan". It doesn't work like that.\n
Art.\n
So, "Phantom Blood" and "Battle Tendency" made a huge success, they gathered audience, earned enough money to keep show popping and film "Stardust Crusaders". And they made... a freaking downgrade? Why would anyone ever do that? Art style is one of the major reasons why fans like this show. And now all characters look like choppy wooden dolls with rectangular faces, scratch marks all over their bodies and enormous shoulders. Nuff said.\n
Overall, I do not recommend watching this to anybody who enjoyed PB and BT, because if so, you will be deeply dissapointed. Do not be fooled with "memes" and stuff, frow now on, they are false advertisement.

I liked the first half, some small pacing issues but the variety of the enemies powers, and the fights they have I loved, very creative I felt.
story:   It follows a family and friends that have powers due to a curse, and having to hunt down a villian whose defeat will stop their powers and others.    It's pretty decent, I liked it, I liked the creativity that went into the various powers.
Art:   this is a tough one, I liked it, but it almost feels at times a tiny bit off like they are doing the thing one piece doesat times, wich is try to translate the manga directly into anime.   May not be for everyone, but the details and art I did like.


Sound:   it's decent, and I loved the closing song, though every time It played I kept half expecting the fresh prince of bel air to start up.


Characters:   this is where the show probably shines the best, everyone has their own motivations and powers, how each power works and so on are neat, and it's not just a straight out battle royal like some anime's where everything is just some variation of beating to death, it can be there at times, but there is a lot of times, where that won't work.


Enjoyment and over all:   I definetly liked the series, and planning on heading straight into season 2 pretty quickly, if you like battle anime's and want something that is a bit different, it's worth a check.

I talked about this already in my review for Phantom Blood, so I'll keep it snappy. 
For me, the remade JoJo series merits a high score not on the sole basis of it's story, originality, plot, etc. It entertained me, and I loved those moments of bizarreness, but whether JoJo is a "good" anime or not is irrelevant. Jojo is an important anime culturally, and that is what interests me. It also happens to have spot-on presentation.
As for this arc specifically, I love the travel-log aspect of the story. I also got attached to the characters even though we learn relatively little about them andthere's not always much pathos behind their motivations. That is all.\n\n
From my own scoring system:\n\n
2/3 for characters and relationships\n
2/3 for plot and story line\n
4/3 for formal elements\n
0/1 for my special award
